Art Deco Space Colony Tourism Board • Vol. 77

Bathtub Bureau & Secret Post

Edition: The Armored Correspondence Special Orbiting Terra Prime Price: 3 brass seals

Lead Story

Post Office for Secrets launches detective agency, announces all operations are from a bathtub.
By Quill Sable, Field Correspondent in Chainmail

“The tub is a command cradle,” says Marshal Plunge

The Secret Post has opened its newest branch: the Bathtub Bureau of Inquiry. The office is an enamel tub, stationed in the civic atrium, with a brass showerhead used as a megaphone. Visitors are asked to remove their boots, not their armor.

“We believe in immersion journalism. Also, the tub is nonnegotiable.”

The dress code is medieval armor “for integrity, not intimidation,” according to the official memo. The agency promises to solve mysteries of misplaced letters, missing moons, and identity theft via pigeon.

The grand opening featured a ribbon-cutting performed by a knight in galoshes. Rumor has it the tub is filled with distilled starlight and a hint of lavender. Residents can now submit clandestine packages via the gutter grate, which doubles as a suggestion box.

Side Bar

Tourism Board Notice

Visit the Art Deco Space Colony! Marble promenades, brass tramcars, and views of the nebula that will make your horoscope feel seen.

Byline Index

Every reporter has a sword. Every sword has a pen attached. This is journalism with a clang.

Metro Orbit

The Pigeon Union negotiates new flight bath breaks

By Lira Buckle, Union Desk

The courier pigeons request two extra splash sessions per shift, arguing their feathers are “informationally saturated.” The Bureau replied by installing a miniature tub on the roof.

Helm-smiths launch “quiet armor” line

By Roan Glass, Civic Industry

Chainmail with felt inlays cuts clinking by 32%. Critics call it “sneak-ily responsible.”

Opinion

Why a bathtub is the only honest office

By Dr. Penelope Rinse, Tub Philosopher

Water does what bureaucracy cannot: it reveals where you leak. A submerged desk is merely truth, amplified. Also, the acoustics in enamel are exquisite for interrogations.

Editorial: armor is the new blazer

By The Board

In a colony built on vacuum and vow, a little chainmail says, “I’m here for duty,” and also, “I might joust for the truth.”

Long Read

The Secret Post’s hidden route map (and why it smells faintly of chamomile)

By Aster Nomad, Investigations

The routes are drawn on bath towels. Each island stop is stitched in terracotta thread. The map looks like a spa menu but reads like an empire’s nervous system.

The detective agency swears the towels were “the only honest parchment left.” Still, a towel’s absorbency makes it perfect for hiding truth in plain sight.

“We are not laundering facts, we are laundering doubt.”

The Tourism Board has already commissioned towel kiosks for visitors. The kiosks will include disclaimers and a complimentary bar of truth soap.

Corrections

Last issue’s “steam whistle” was a “scream whistle.”

We regret the confusion and the slight panic during the ribbon cutting.

We referred to the tub as porcelain. It is enamel. The tub insists.

We have issued a written apology and a polishing rag.

Feature: The Armored Dress Code

How to dress for secrets without drowning in dignity

By Calder Moss, Style Editor

The correct look is a blend of practicality and pageantry: a cuirass over a towel, greaves with rubber soles, and a visor that flips quietly.

“Our lookbook is half knight, half lifeguard.”

Designers insist the palette remains terracotta, olive, and burnished gold. As one tailor put it, “It’s Deco, but your joints can move.”
